newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Result restores faith in The Warehouse.
newsitem.headline: Result restores faith in The Warehouse.

text.p: A big earnings turnaround in The Warehouse Group Ltd has restored the market's faith in the retailer, and analysts said on Thursday they were now looking at a full year result above NZ$30 million.
The discount chain on Wednesday reported earnings of NZ$25.3 million for the six months to January. Most analysts had expected a result under $20 million.
The company, which has changed to a January 31 balance date from a March 31 date, reported a NZ$5.26 million profit in the four months to July 31.
"There is probably some conjecture on what it means for the full year result still, but it definitely restores the company's credibility," said one analyst, who declined to be identified.

The Warehouse was caned by the market when it last year reported an annual result of NZ$23.11 million, down sharply from $35.23 million a year earlier and radically lower than market expectations. The stock at one point was driven down to NZ$2.00 -- its lowest point since listing in November, 1994.
Overstocking and systems problems were blamed for the poor outcome.
"It's a continuation of the rebuilding of its credibility after the hiccup of 1996 and the market loves them again," the analyst said.
"There had been a lot of doubters in the market. I guess they've got their act together a little quicker than people thought in terms of manning costs and other such things."
Analysts said there was some suggestion the period may have been more buoyant seasonally than originally thought.
Most now expected an annual result over NZ$30 million. The range of forecasts was wide, though an outcome in the high $30 millions was seen as unlikely.
A clearer picture for the full year is expected to emerge when the company holds briefings on Friday.
The positive earnings surprise boosted the stock to a high for the year of NZ$3.75, later easing to NZ$3.67, which was 47 cents up on Wednesday's close.
The Warehouse is 53 percent owned by its principal, Stephen Tindall, and the Tindall foundation.
The AMP Society revealed on Monday that it held 8.09 percent, but brokers said the sharp gain in price was purely result-related and nothing to do with illiquidity.
Warren Couillault, retail analyst at SBC Warburg, said The Warehouse had gone through a restoration process over the last six months.
"I suppose the surprise is that margins have rebounded quite strongly. Most people were forecasting pretty strong gains but it was a bit of a surprise across the board," he said.
"None of that result is assistance from the economy. It's 100 percent them getting their act together and taking out costs they incurred last year."
